div.p:
I calculate as the Americans
say that this will find the Lady of
Lochore with her Schwazritter Schwarz=
Ritter as a friend of mine calls Walter
(alleging that he is a croat in disguize disguise
and that he longs to ask him about
the battle of Austerlitz) I say I hope that
this will find the black hussar and
his little bride at quiet mornings at
Edgeworthstown though I suppose
the gentleman's stay will be very
brief. I hope my dear little Jane will
get over her fears and that to such advantage
as her quiet nature will permit as with
all her humility and shyness she has at
the foundation a strong share both of
principle and good sense with fortitude
where it is necessary. I am anxious to
hear that she is safe as your side of
that vile channel and under the
protection of the kind friends who

have offerd offered her hospitality
You wished to have for a mutual
friend I think one of Spice's puppies I
did not send you one of any indeed
keep any of the first little which is
seldom good for much but she will
have a family this spring & as the Sire
is of high favor and he herself one of
best-bred terriers in Scotland I wish
to know whether you still wish me
to keep one a whelp and whether it
should be male or female or if you
would prefer a brace. Spice is quite
recovered of her Asthma notwithstanding
Miss Harriets most anxious dream
She dispatches rats and vermin in
the most knowing stile style and is an
extremely kind & sociable creature She
is a capital specimen of the,
Fierce terriers wont in high- hilld hilled
Liddesdale
To storm the wild-cat's lodge and badgers
rough

How does your literary undertaking come
on? and have you determined to play
the incognita? if so it will cost you bold
fibbing if it can be termed so when one
denies what no one has a right to enquire inquire
into. Have you heard from Mrs Fox Lane
whose absence at this time I sincerely
regret as I know she would have been
kind to Jane. I hope she will bring
some Venetian or Sicilian ballads home
with her the prettiest musical
impor-
tations
importations in the opinion of such vulgar
hearers as I am. We are rather lonely
here having nobody but Lady S. Anne
and myself at Abbotsford Lockhart's
business detaining him in town: the
want of Sophia and little Johnie is
rather annoying I have given Johnie
a pony so very small that it is less
than many dogs otherwise so beautiful
made & so calm that it might serve
the King of Lilliput God save his grace.

Johnie with a little assistance rides
into the hall and dining parlour and
like the minstrels of old "up to the
fur board-head" and the pony per
-fectly perfectly understands, the value of a
clumsy piece of bread When I write
about these trifles you may be sure I
have little else to say. The people are
all much here about joint stock
compa
-nies
companies and the madness which possesses
John Bull has caught his speculative
brother Sawney No man can commit
the extremity of fully with so grave a
countenance and under the influence
of such admirable reasoning as a
Scotchman The whole nation indeed de
sires the church is given to the Sapient
Monarch of old "that of the wisest fools
in Christendom." Such folly however
has a better chance to pass unnoticed
as the perpetrator completely possesses
his own self opinion. They treat laughers
as

as the Newcastle Keel-men did the owl. The keel (a parti
cular particular boat for carrying the coal down the Tyne) had run ashore
under the ruins of the old abbey of Jarrow and the shock startled
out an owl from her place of strength the Hand who was afore
having never seen such bird in his life concluded from its
appearance & cry that it must be a spirit and exhorted his com
-rade comrade to come ahead & speak to it which he did to this purpose
The supposed ghost you must understand had treated them
with two or three shrieks "Hoo! hoo!" said the keeler who thought
the expression of the owls wonder too strong for the occasion " What's
thee hoo hoo-ing at - didst never see a keel ashore before?" I
believe we shall see a few keels
Ashore before the play is playd played
out whether we are all allowed to
laugh at them or no. We are
endeavouring
endeavoring to profit by the
mania to get a rail road
brought up from Kelso which
would accomodate a valuable track of country with coal and
lime from which we are twenty miles distant We had a meeting
of our committee here on tuesday on which occasion Anne (who
is a decided punstress) hearing more of the undertaking I supposed
than she relished observed if our conversation was deficient
in wit there was no want of raillery. Did it ever strike you
that Anne (talent apart) has an odd cast of Beatrices
humour humor
